required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on December 16, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Gut Microbiota, the Potential Key to Modulating Humoral Immunogenicity of New Platform COVID-19 Vaccines
clinical_study.official_title: Gut Microbiota, the Potential Key to Modulating Humoral Immunogenicity of New Platform COVID-19 Vaccines: Adenovirus-vectored Vaccine Versus mRNA Vaccine

brief_summary.textblock: Vaccination is the best way to mitigate the coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) pandemic, but the vaccine immunogenicity may be quite variable from person to person. There is increasing evidence suggesting that the gut microbiome is a major determinant of vaccine immunogenicity. Thus, the investigators investigated the relationship between gut microbiota and humoral immune response after COVID-19 vaccination.

primary_outcome.description: This study aimed to analyze whether fecal microbiota composition before vaccination was associated with immmune response level

secondary_outcome.measure: Antibody titres after the first dose vaccination
secondary_outcome.time_frame: 3weeks from the first-dose administration in BNT162b2 group, 8-12weeks from the first-dose administration in ChAdOx1
secondary_outcome.description: This study aimed to analyze maximum immune response after first dose vaccination

secondary_outcome.measure: Antibody titres after the second dose vaccination
secondary_outcome.time_frame: 3 weeks from the second dose administration in both BNT162b2 and ChAdOx1 groups
secondary_outcome.description: This study aimed to analyze maximum immune response after second dose vaccination

arm_group.description: From Febrary 25, 2021 to July 16, 2021, healthy healthcare workers were prospectively recruited at a tertiary hospital in Seoul, Republic of Korea, and they were assigned to get ChAdOx1 (Oxford/AstraZeneca) (n=26) vaccines. Participants were excluded if they had history of medication which would affect gut microbiota in the past 1 month, including antibiotics, laxatives, and motility drugs; previous history of positive SARS-CoV-2 test on nasopharyngeal PCR; or positive serum Spike IgG results.

From Febrary 25, 2021 to July 16, 2021, 53 healthy healthcare workers were prospectively recruited at a tertiary hospital in Seoul, Republic of Korea, and they were assigned to get BNT162b2 (n=27) vaccines. Participants were excluded if they had history of medication which would affect gut microbiota in the past 1 month, including antibiotics, laxatives, and motility drugs; previous history of positive SARS-CoV-2 test on nasopharyngeal PCR; or positive serum Spike IgG results.

intervention.description: We enrolled the healthcare workers assigned to get either BNT162b2 or ChAdOx1 by the Korean government.

study_pop.textblock: From Febrary 25, 2021 to July 16, 2021, 53 healthy healthcare workers were prospectively recruited at a tertiary hospital in Seoul, Republic of Korea, and they were assigned to get either BNT162b2 (n=27) or ChAdOx1 (Oxford/AstraZeneca) (n=26) vaccines. Participants were excluded if they had history of medication which would affect gut microbiota in the past 1 month, including antibiotics, laxatives, and motility drugs; previous history of positive SARS-CoV-2 test on nasopharyngeal PCR; or positive serum Spike IgG results.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- People assigned to get either BNT162b2 or ChAdOx1 vaccines
- informed concents
Exclusion Criteria:
- Participants were excluded if they had a history of medication which would affect gut microbiota in the past 1 month, including antibiotics, laxatives, and motility drugs.
